author: andreas
content: I'd say the quality is varying. At least the D200 profiles were not that good, I don't think I tried for the D300. But yes, I see the point. The other problem with ISO-based profiles is, that ISO as recorded in the meta data does not tell that much about the actual noise reduction needs. A high-contrast night shot is different from a twilight shot with sky, and it so much depends on where your information is. In difficult situations I tend to use "Select Color Range"-based masks, for instance to restrict smudging over details to the sky. In the end though, I think noise reduction algorithms are as good as their ability to detect edges within random noise. That's something that the Topaz products do very well.
